image.altText: A person in a hi-vis vest and white hard hat walks alongside a port with a golden retriever sniffing dog besides them

items.synopsis: Follow the path cocaine takes from Colombian bush labs to your local suburbs — and the battle to intercept it.

title.children: 'Nobody pretends we check every container': The uphill battle to keep coke out of Australia

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin is seen through an open window sitting in teh back of a black four-wheel-drive

items.synopsis: Wagner mercenary boss Yevgeny Prigozhin orders his fighters to turn back from their march towards Moscow.

title.children: Kremlin says charges against Prigozhin will be dropped, Wagner fighters leave Rostov-on-Don — as it happened

image.altText: Wagner mercenary fighters on top of a tank, with a Wagner flag.

items.synopsis: Wagner troops leave Rostov-on-Don and Yevgeny Prigozhin will move to Belarus under a deal brokered by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko to end the mutiny.

title.children: Wagner Group retreating from Russia, leader Prigozhin to move to Belarus

image.altText: Russian President Vladimir Putin gives a televised address.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to launch a full-scale war against Ukraine has backfired catastrophically, so much so that it may end up leading to his downfall, writes Steve Cannane.

title.children: Putin has never looked so vulnerable, and it's due to his own creations

image.altText: A white woman with curly brown hair and glasses, stands at her front door

items.synopsis: A trip to the doctor or hospital can be a traumatic experience for trans and gender diverse people, with one in two patients reporting a negative experience. Some GPs and medical students are trying to change that.

title.children: Transgender woman Rosie avoids going to hospital when she is in mental health crisis because of discrimination

image.altText: A homeless man sits on a blanket on a footpath wearing a hoodie.

items.synopsis: More than half the people released from Risdon Prison this year will be exiting into some form of homelessness — with more than half of those ending up back behind bars.

title.children: Prisoners released into homelessness, ending up back in jail

image.altText: A composite image of two Facebook ads, run by the Yes and No Voice campaigns.

items.synopsis: Both sides of the Voice to Parliament referendum campaign are starting to spend big on social media advertising, and where they’re directing their dollars gives us some clues about their strategies, writes Casey Briggs.

title.children: The Voice No campaign has spied a path to victory, and it hangs on Australia's smallest states

image.altText: A portrait of Mandy looking into the camera. Her van is behind her. The back is open. Many items are inside.

items.synopsis: The rise in homelessness is easy to see across Australia, with more rough sleepers on streets and tent cities in parks. But there's a group experiencing homelessness who prefer to go unnoticed — the growing number of people living in vehicles.

title.children: 'Van life' is glamorised on social media. Here's the reality for one woman whose car is now home

image.altText: A man and a woman in brightly coloured vests stand outside a pink building talking at sunset

items.synopsis: In the 12 months since the US Supreme Court overturned the law enshrining abortion rights nationwide, the landscape has drastically changed. Abortion is now prohibited or heavily restricted for millions of Americans, and providers are worried their most vulnerable patients will continue to suffer.

title.children: One year since the US Supreme Court overturned abortion rights, a new fight is looming

image.altText: Pedestrian walks past Reserve Bank building in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank says it needs unemployment to rise to bring inflation down, and we should welcome their plain speaking, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: The Reserve Bank wants more unemployment. It should be applauded for admitting it

image.altText: A woman in a brown shirt and floral skirt sits on some stairs with a typewriter

items.synopsis: When both people in a relationship are writers, creative space is a fault line. So are matters such as who looks after the kids, inspiration turf wars, and jealousy about success. Still, it's often the wives who ultimately choose writing over wedded bliss, writes Kerrie Davies.

title.children: Two writers, two careers, one relationship: Inside the literary couples where success was shared — and not equally

image.altText: A man walking cattle through dusty yards

items.synopsis: An intense herd rebuild has left Australia with more cattle for market, and graziers and consumers alike are set to benefit.

title.children: Cheaper steaks on the way as more meat heads to market

image.altText: Woman wearing a patterned blue dress and red glasses smiles, with her hands together. Tropical trees are in the background.

items.synopsis: As international students struggle to find accommodation, more Australians than ever before are renting out their spare bedrooms — and it's helping pay the bills.

title.children: 'If you've got a spare bedroom, you can turn it into tax-free income': More Australians hosting international students

image.altText: The back of a small dog looking out a small plane window.

items.synopsis: More than 20,000 pets fly in and out of Australia each year, most in the cargo hold of commercial aircraft. But as demand grows for pets to fly in style alongside their owners, a new service is taking off.

title.children: The people flying their pets around the world in private jets to avoid putting them in the cargo hold with luggage

image.altText: Three women in Edwardian dress posing by a waterfall.

items.synopsis: Modern-day adventurers step back in time to recreate the hiking experiences of a pair of  Tasmanian pioneering conservationists who campaigned for the protection of Cradle Mountain.

title.children: 'We get a lot of Picnic at Hanging Rock references': The Tasmanian bushwalkers who dress like it's the early 1900s

image.altText: Woman with hair pulled back, wearing funky black glasses and a green jumper smiles slightly at camera

items.synopsis: Lily Foster battled addiction for 20 years and "lost" everything. She wants to share her "lived experience" so others can benefit but in Tasmania, it's not easy for her to make her voice heard.

title.children: 'I lost everything to addiction': Lily wants to share what she's learned to help others

image.altText: Silhouetted figure of a woman to the left, farm gate to the right. Sunset in the centre

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal there is a court battle to keep a man who abducted and raped a German backpacker 10 years ago behind bars, with forensic psychiatrists fearing he was a high risk of reoffending.

title.children: A German backpacker responded to an ad to nanny in remote Queensland. It was a sex offender's trap

image.altText: Security personnel keep watch outside the Wuhan Institute of Virology during the visit by the World Health Organisation.

items.synopsis: US intelligence report on COVID-19 origins rejects some points raised by lab leak theory proponents.

title.children: No direct evidence COVID started in Wuhan lab, US report finds

image.altText: A woman standing outside holding a black and white cat that is wearing a bib.

items.synopsis: Experts say roaming pet cats are killings millions of native wildlife annually but there is a tool to help mitigate this.

title.children: Cat bibs are being trialled to stop pets killing wildlife, but keeping cats indoors is still best

image.altText: Photo of wagyu flock next to photo of hemp crop.

items.synopsis: A farming family is feeding their livestock hemp-based pellets, testing impacts on health and meat quality.

title.children: Farmers trial hemp feed for cattle, marron to see if it boosts healthy omegas in the meat?

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios gives side-eye while wearing all black at a press conference.

items.synopsis: 2022 Wimbledon finalist Nick Kyrgios has pulled out of another grass-court warm-up event, leaving his prospects of a big run at the grand slam looking bleak.

title.children: Wimbledon fears for Nick Kyrgios after Mallorca withdrawal

image.altText: A man stands beside a broken-down vehicle with a big yellow sign on the side saying 'help' in black letters.

items.synopsis: Australia's stunning landscapes can be perilous for the unprepared. Two outdoor experts and an intrepid hiker give their tips for surviving in the alps, the outback and the tropics.

title.children: Why a 'MacGyver kit' could stop a camping emergency from becoming a tragedy

image.altText: Nurses and doctor pictured during medical procedure, generic image.

items.synopsis: The controversial tool has been implemented in Auckland, taking a person's ethnicity into account when placing them on non-urgent surgery waitlists.

title.children: Ethnicity criteria to rank patients for surgery in New Zealand labelled 'a courageous move'

image.altText: A close up of a stone cross on top of a church roof with grey background.

items.synopsis: A former Catholic priest who is serving a prison sentence for sexually abusing schoolboys in Victoria, will be sentenced over more indecent assault charges in Tasmania.

title.children: Victim felt responsible for the abuse of other schoolboys

image.altText: Creekbed and road overflowing with water outside a house

items.synopsis: A rainband stretching more than 3,000 kilometres will engulf Australia next week, delivering soaking rains from the Pilbara and Kimberley, across the outback to the eastern seaboard.

title.children: Week-long drenching forecast across Australia as El Niño takes a rain check

image.altText: Dougal, Madeleine and the appraiser Caroline Jones look closely at the club.

items.synopsis: For keen collectors, estate beneficiaries, and garage sale-seekers, it was an offer too good to refuse — a "no fee, no obligation" expert appraisal of their treasures.

title.children: As the cost of living rises, some Australians are holding onto antiques as a safety net while others are selling off collectibles

image.altText: Errol Gulden runs off in celebration as Eagles players look on behind him

items.synopsis: Sydney pile the pain on the hapless West Coast Eagles, who suffer a club-record 171-point loss at the SCG, while Fremantle steady the ship with a crucial 32-point win over Essendon.

title.children: Swans crack 200 to hand Eagles record loss, Freo fire back with win over Bombers

image.altText: Female hands holding a mobile phone with a dark background.

items.synopsis: A man has helped police track his allegedly stolen ute using a phone app before the driver crashed into a patrol vehicle in the Adelaide Hills.

title.children: Phone app tracks stolen ute as police swoop on alleged thieves

image.altText: Man makes a coffee at a machine in a cafe.

items.synopsis: Hospitality businesses are raising prices, reducing trading hours and considering scrapping loyalty perks as they struggle to cope with cost of living pressures.

title.children: Paying more for coffee lately? Cafes warn prices will keep rising in 'vicious cycle'

image.altText: A woman holds a bucket of oyster shells in front of the Opera House.

items.synopsis: An Indigenous artist enlists the public's help to clean tens of thousands of oyster shells for a new sculpture reminding visitors of Bennelong Point/Tubowgule's cultural significance.

title.children: Indigenous artist recreates midden at Sydney's Opera House with help of 'scrub club'

image.altText: a picture of one of the Bays on Magnetic Island and surrounding rainforest

items.synopsis: The 26-year-old tourist had celebrated her birthday just last week, according to her employer.

title.children: 'She was a great friend': Belgian tourist dies after motor-scooter crash on island off Queensland coast

image.altText: An Australian female professional golfer watches the progress of a shot down the fairway.

items.synopsis: West Australian Minjee Lee makes her move on the leaderboard at the Women's PGA Championship as she tries to claim her third major.

title.children: Lee rockets up the leaderboard as she looks to claim third major in three years

image.altText: Steven Schwartz pictured outside court with a mobile phone and paper work in his hands.

items.synopsis: The US lawyer, a colleague and their Manhattan law firm were fined for submitting fake citations in a court filing.

title.children: 'Use with caution': How ChatGPT landed this US lawyer and his firm in hot water

image.altText: Palestinians take cover during an Israeli raid in Jenin.

items.synopsis: The United Nations human rights high commissioner says conflict in the West Bank is deteriorating sharply, calling on Israel to reset its policies and comply with international law.

title.children: UN calls out Israel for 'use of advanced military weaponry' in deadly West Bank clashes

image.altText: A submersible under sea with air bubbles coming out from the top.

items.synopsis: OceanGate co-founder Guillermo Sohnlein defends the company's deceased CEO against claims he dismissed safety warnings, as officials work to decide who will investigate the disaster.

title.children: 'Keenly aware of the risks': OceanGate co-founder defends dead CEO's approach to safety as probe launched
